Downtown [Whitehorse](/wiki/Whitehorse,_Yukon "Whitehorse, Yukon") along the
[Yukon River](/wiki/Yukon_River "Yukon River")

**Yukon**[6] ([/ˈjuːkɒn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"); French:
[[jykɔ̃]](/wiki/Help:IPA/French "Help:IPA/French"); also commonly called **the
Yukon**) is the smallest and westernmost of [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada")'s
three federal [territories](/wiki/Canadian_Territories "Canadian Territories")
(the other two are the [Northwest Territories](/wiki/Northwest_Territories
"Northwest Territories") and [Nunavut](/wiki/Nunavut "Nunavut")). The
territory has the smallest population of any province or territory in Canada,
with 35,874 people.[7] [Whitehorse](/wiki/Whitehorse,_Yukon "Whitehorse,
Yukon") is the territorial [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and
Yukon's only [city](/wiki/City "City").

The territory was split from the [Northwest
Territories](/wiki/Northwest_Territories "Northwest Territories") in 1898 and
was named the **Yukon Territory**. The federal government's _Yukon Act_ ,
which received royal assent on March 27, 2002, established _Yukon_ as the
territory's official name,[6] though _Yukon Territory_ is also still popular
in usage and [Canada Post](/wiki/Canada_Post "Canada Post") continues to use
the territory's internationally approved postal abbreviation of _YT_.[8]
Though officially bilingual (English and French), the Yukon Government also
recognizes [First Nations](/wiki/First_Nations "First Nations") languages.

At 5,959 m (19,551 ft), Yukon's [Mount Logan](/wiki/Mount_Logan "Mount
Logan"), in [Kluane National Park and
Reserve](/wiki/Kluane_National_Park_and_Reserve "Kluane National Park and
Reserve"), is the highest mountain in Canada and the second-highest on the
[North American](/wiki/North_America "North America") continent (after
[Denali](/wiki/Denali "Denali") in the [U.S. state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S.
state") of [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska")). Most of Yukon has a [subarctic
climate](/wiki/Subarctic_climate "Subarctic climate"), characterized by long
cold winters and brief warm summers. The [Arctic Ocean](/wiki/Arctic_Ocean
"Arctic Ocean") coast has a [tundra climate](/wiki/Tundra_climate "Tundra
climate").

Notable rivers include the [Yukon River](/wiki/Yukon_River "Yukon River"),
after which the territory was named, as well as the Pelly, Stewart, Peel,
White and Tatshenshini rivers.

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

The territory is named after the [Yukon River](/wiki/Yukon_River "Yukon
River"), the longest river in Yukon. The name itself is from a
[contraction](/wiki/Contraction_\(grammar\) "Contraction \(grammar\)") of the
words in the [Gwich'in](/wiki/Gwich%E2%80%99in_language "Gwich’in language")
phrase _chųų gąįį han_ , which means _white water river_ and refers to “the
pale colour” of [glacial runoff](/wiki/Rock_flour "Rock flour") in the Yukon
River.[9][10]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: History")]

Main article: [History of Yukon](/wiki/History_of_Yukon "History of Yukon")

Long before the arrival of [Europeans](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), central and
southern Yukon was populated by First Nations people, and the area escaped
[glaciation](/wiki/Glacier "Glacier"). Sites of
[archeological](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") significance in Yukon hold
some of the earliest evidence of the presence of human occupation in North
America.[11][12] The sites safeguard the history of the first people and the
earliest First Nations of the Yukon.[12]

The [volcanic](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano") eruption of [Mount
Churchill](/wiki/Mount_Churchill "Mount Churchill") in approximately 800 AD in
what is now the U.S. state of Alaska blanketed southern Yukon with a layer of
[ash](/wiki/Volcanic_ash "Volcanic ash") which can still be seen along the
[Klondike Highway](/wiki/Klondike_Highway "Klondike Highway"), and which forms
part of the oral tradition of First Nations peoples in Yukon and further south
in Canada.

Coastal and inland First Nations had extensive trading networks. European
incursions into the area only began early in the 19th century with the [fur
trade](/wiki/Fur_trade "Fur trade"), followed by
[missionaries](/wiki/Missionary "Missionary"). By the 1870s and 1880s gold
miners began to arrive. This drove a population increase that justified the
establishment of a police force, just in time for the start of the [Klondike
Gold Rush](/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush "Klondike Gold Rush") in 1897. The
increased population coming with the gold rush led to the separation of the
Yukon district from the Northwest Territories and the formation of the
separate Yukon Territory in 1898.

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Geography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Yukonwikimap.PNG/300px-
Yukonwikimap.PNG)](/wiki/File:Yukonwikimap.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Yukonwikimap.PNG "Enlarge")

Map of Yukon

Main article: [Geography of Yukon](/wiki/Geography_of_Yukon "Geography of
Yukon")

The territory is the approximate shape of a [right
triangle](/wiki/Right_triangle "Right triangle"), bordering the U.S. state of
Alaska to the west and northwest for 1,210 km (752 mi) mostly along longitude
141° W, the Northwest Territories to the east and British Columbia to the
south.[13] Its northern coast is on the [Beaufort Sea](/wiki/Beaufort_Sea
"Beaufort Sea"). Its ragged eastern boundary mostly follows the
[divide](/wiki/Drainage_divide "Drainage divide") between the Yukon Basin and
the [Mackenzie River](/wiki/Mackenzie_River "Mackenzie River") [drainage
basin](/wiki/Drainage_basin "Drainage basin") to the east in the Mackenzie
mountains.

Most of the territory is in the watershed of its namesake, the Yukon River.
The southern Yukon is dotted with a large number of large, long and narrow
glacier-fed alpine lakes, most of which flow into the Yukon River system. The
larger lakes include [Teslin Lake](/wiki/Teslin_Lake "Teslin Lake"), [Atlin
Lake](/wiki/Atlin_Lake "Atlin Lake"), [Tagish Lake](/wiki/Tagish_Lake "Tagish
Lake"), [Marsh Lake](/wiki/Marsh_Lake "Marsh Lake"), [Lake
Laberge](/wiki/Lake_Laberge "Lake Laberge"), [Kusawa Lake](/wiki/Kusawa_Lake
"Kusawa Lake") and [Kluane Lake](/wiki/Kluane_Lake "Kluane Lake"). [Bennett
Lake](/wiki/Bennett_Lake "Bennett Lake") on the [Klondike Gold
Rush](/wiki/Klondike,_Yukon "Klondike, Yukon") trail is a lake flowing into
Nares Lake, with the greater part of its area within Yukon.

Canada's highest point, Mount Logan (5,959 m or 19,551 ft), is in the
territory's southwest. Mount Logan and a large part of the Yukon's southwest
are in [Kluane National Park and
Reserve](/wiki/Kluane_National_Park_and_Reserve "Kluane National Park and
Reserve"), a UNESCO [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World
Heritage Site"). Other national parks include [Ivvavik National
Park](/wiki/Ivvavik_National_Park "Ivvavik National Park") and [Vuntut
National Park](/wiki/Vuntut_National_Park "Vuntut National Park") in the
north.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Mount_Logan.jpg/250px-
Mount_Logan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mount_Logan.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mount_Logan.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mount Logan](/wiki/Mount_Logan "Mount Logan") from the southeast

Other watersheds include the Mackenzie River, the [Peel
Watershed](/wiki/Peel_Watershed "Peel Watershed") and the
[Alsek](/wiki/Alsek_River "Alsek
River")–[Tatshenshini](/wiki/Tatshenshini_River "Tatshenshini River"), and a
number of rivers flowing directly into the Beaufort Sea. The two main Yukon
rivers flowing into the Mackenzie in the Northwest Territories are the [Liard
River](/wiki/Liard_River "Liard River") in the southeast and the [Peel
River](/wiki/Peel_River_\(Canada\) "Peel River \(Canada\)") and its
tributaries in the northeast.

Notable widespread tree species within Yukon are the [black
spruce](/wiki/Black_spruce "Black spruce") and [white
spruce](/wiki/White_spruce "White spruce"). Many trees are stunted because of
the short growing season and severe climate.[14]

The capital, [Whitehorse](/wiki/Whitehorse,_Yukon "Whitehorse, Yukon"), is
also the largest city, with about three-quarters of the population; the second
largest is [Dawson City](/wiki/Dawson_City,_Yukon "Dawson City, Yukon") (pop.
2,016), which was the capital until 1952.

### Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Climate")]

See also: [Climate change in the Arctic](/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_Arctic
"Climate change in the Arctic")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Yukon_koppen.svg/220px-
Yukon_koppen.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Yukon_koppen.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Yukon_koppen.svg "Enlarge")

Köppen climate types in Yukon

While the average winter temperature in the Yukon is mild by Canadian arctic
standards, no other place in North America gets as cold as the Yukon during
extreme cold snaps. The temperature has dropped down to −60 °C (−76 °F) three
times, 1947, 1954, and 1968. The most extreme cold snap occurred in February
1947 when the abandoned town of [Snag](/wiki/Snag,_Yukon "Snag, Yukon")
dropped down to −63.0 °C (−81.4 °F).[15]

Unlike most of Canada where the most extreme heat waves occur in July, August,
and even September, The Yukon's extreme heat tends to occur in June and even
May. The Yukon has recorded 36 °C (97 °F) three times. The first time was in
June 1969 when [Mayo](/wiki/Mayo,_Yukon "Mayo, Yukon") recorded a temperature
of 36.1 °C (97 °F). 14 years later this record was almost beaten when [Forty
Mile](/wiki/Forty_Mile,_Yukon "Forty Mile, Yukon") recorded 36 °C (97 °F) in
May 1983. The old record was finally broken 21 years later in June 2004 when
the Mayo Road weather station, located just northwest of
[Whitehorse](/wiki/Whitehorse,_Yukon "Whitehorse, Yukon"), recorded a
temperature of 36.5 °C (97.7 °F).[16]

section: Demographics")]

Main article: [Demographics of Yukon](/wiki/Demographics_of_Yukon
"Demographics of Yukon")

The population of Yukon in the [2016 census](/wiki/Canada_2016_Census "Canada
2016 Census") is 35,874, an increase of 5.8% from 2011.[2] With a land area of
474,712.64 km2 (183,287.57 sq mi), it had a population density of 0.1/km2
(0.2/sq mi) in 2011.[17]

### Ethnicity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Ethnicity")]

![Ambox current red.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ambox_current_red.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red.svg.png) |  This article's **[factual accuracy](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute "Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") may be compromised due to out-of-date information**. Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. _(April 2017)_  
---|---  
  
According to the [2006 Canada Census](/wiki/2006_Canada_Census "2006 Canada
Census") the majority of the territory's population was of European descent,
although it has a significant population of [First
Nations](/wiki/First_Nations "First Nations") communities across the
territory.

The top ten ancestries were:[21]

Ranking | Ethnic group | Population  
---|---|---  
1. | [English](/wiki/English_people "English people") | 8,795  
2. | [North American First Nations](/wiki/North_American_First_Nations "North American First Nations") | 7,070  
3. | [Scottish](/wiki/Scottish_people "Scottish people") | 7,005  
4. | [Canadian](/wiki/Canadians "Canadians") | 6,075  
5. | [Irish](/wiki/Irish_people "Irish people") | 5,735  
6. | [German](/wiki/Germans "Germans") | 4,835  
7. | [French](/wiki/French_people "French people") | 4,330  
8. | [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainians "Ukrainians") | 1,620  
9. | [Dutch (Netherlands)](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") | 1,475  
10. | [Norwegian](/wiki/Norwegians "Norwegians") | 1,340  
  
The 2011 National Household Survey examined Yukon's ethnocultural diversity
and immigration. At that time, 87.7% of residents were Canadian-born and 24.2%
were of Aboriginal origin. The most common countries of birth for immigrants
were the United Kingdom (15.9%), the Philippines (15.0%), and the United
States (13.2%). Among very recent immigrants (between 2006 and 2011) living in
Yukon, 63.5% were born in Asia.[22]

The most commonly reported mother tongue among the 33,145 single responses to
the [2011 Canadian census](/wiki/Canada_2011_Census "Canada 2011 Census") was
English at 28,065 (7001850000000000000♠85%).[24] The second-most common was
1,455 (7000400000000000000♠4%) for French.[24] Among 510 multiple respondents,
140 of them (7001270000000000000♠27%) reported a mother tongue of both English
and French, while 335 (7001660000000000000♠66%) reported English and a 'non-
official language' and 20 (7000400000000000000♠4%) reported French and a 'non-
official language'.[24]

The Yukon _Language Act_ "recognises the significance" of aboriginal languages
in Yukon; however, only English and French are available for laws, court
proceedings, and legislative assembly proceedings.[25]

### Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Religion")]

![Ambox current red.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ambox_current_red.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red.svg.png) |  This article's **[factual accuracy](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute "Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") may be compromised due to out-of-date information**. Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. _(May 2012)_  
---|---  
  
The 2011 National Household Survey reported that 49.9% of Yukoners reported
having no religious affiliation, the highest percentage in Canada. The most
frequently reported religious affiliation was
[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"), reported by 46.2% of
residents. Of these, the most common denominations were the [Catholic
Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") (39.6%), the [Anglican Church
of Canada](/wiki/Anglican_Church_of_Canada "Anglican Church of Canada")
(17.8%) and the [United Church of Canada](/wiki/United_Church_of_Canada
"United Church of Canada") (9.6%).[26]

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Economy")]

Yukon's historical major industry was [mining](/wiki/Mining "Mining")
([lead](/wiki/Lead "Lead"), [zinc](/wiki/Zinc "Zinc"), [silver](/wiki/Silver
"Silver"), [gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold"), [asbestos](/wiki/Asbestos "Asbestos")
and [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper")). The government acquired the land from
the [Hudson's Bay Company](/wiki/Hudson%27s_Bay_Company "Hudson's Bay
Company") in 1870 and split it from the [Northwest
Territories](/wiki/Northwest_Territories "Northwest Territories") in 1898 to
fill the need for local government created by the population influx of the
gold rush.

Thousands of these prospectors flooded the territory, creating a colourful
period recorded by authors such as [Robert W. Service](/wiki/Robert_W._Service
"Robert W. Service") and [Jack London](/wiki/Jack_London "Jack London"). The
memory of this period and the early days of the [Royal Canadian Mounted
Police](/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Mounted_Police "Royal Canadian Mounted Police"),
as well as the territory's scenic wonders and outdoor recreation
opportunities, makes [tourism](/wiki/Tourism "Tourism") the second most
important industry.

Manufacturing, including furniture, clothing, and handicrafts, follows in
importance, along with [hydroelectricity](/wiki/Hydroelectricity
"Hydroelectricity"). The traditional industries of
[trapping](/wiki/Animal_trapping "Animal trapping") and
[fishing](/wiki/Fishing "Fishing") have declined. Today, the government sector
is by far the biggest employer in the territory, directly employing
approximately 5,000 out of a labour force of 12,500, on a population of
36,500.[27]

On 1 May 2015, Yukon modified its Business Corporations Act,[28][29][30] in an
effort to attract more benefits and participants to its economy. One amendment
to the BCA lets a proxy be given for voting purposes. Another change will
allow directors to pursue business opportunities declined by the corporation,
a practice off-limits in most other jurisdictions due to the inherent
potential for conflicts of interest.[27] One of the changes will allow a
corporation to serve as a director of a subsidiary registered in Yukon.[31]
The legislation also allows companies to add provisions in their articles of
incorporation giving directors blanket approval to sell of all of the
company’s assets without requiring a shareholder vote.[31] If provided for by
a unanimous shareholders agreement, a corporation is not required to have
directors at all.[32] There is increased flexibility regarding the location of
corporate records offices, including the ability to maintain a records office
outside of the Yukon so long as it is accessible by electronic means.[32]

### Tourism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Tourism")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Yukon_border_sign.jpg/220px-
Yukon_border_sign.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yukon_border_sign.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yukon_border_sign.jpg "Enlarge")

Yukon welcome sign

Yukon's tourism motto is "Larger than life".[33] Yukon's major appeal is its
nearly pristine nature. Tourism relies heavily on this, and there are many
organized [outfitters](/wiki/Outfitter "Outfitter") and [guides](/wiki/Guide
"Guide") available to [hunters](/wiki/Hunting "Hunting") and
[anglers](/wiki/Fisherman "Fisherman") and nature lovers of all sorts. Sports
enthusiasts can paddle lakes and rivers with [canoes](/wiki/Canoe "Canoe") and
[kayaks](/wiki/Kayak "Kayak"), ride or walk trails, [ski](/wiki/Ski "Ski") or
[snowboard](/wiki/Snowboard "Snowboard") in an organized setting or access the
[backcountry](/wiki/Backcountry_skiing "Backcountry skiing") by air or
[snowmobile](/wiki/Snowmobile "Snowmobile"), climb the highest peaks in
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") or take a family hike up smaller mountains, or
try [ice climbing](/wiki/Ice_climbing "Ice climbing") and [dog
sledding](/wiki/Dog_sled "Dog sled"). There are also various festivals and
sporting events such as the [Yukon International Storytelling
Festival](/wiki/Yukon_International_Storytelling_Festival "Yukon International
Storytelling Festival") and [Yukon Sourdough
Rendezvous](/wiki/Yukon_Sourdough_Rendezvous "Yukon Sourdough Rendezvous").

There are many opportunities to experience pre-colonial lifestyles by learning
about Yukon's First Nations.[34] Wildlife and nature observation is
exceptional and a wide variety of large [mammals](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal"),
[birds](/wiki/Bird "Bird"), and [fish](/wiki/Fish "Fish") are easily
accessible, whether or not within Yukon's many territorial[35]
[parks](/wiki/Park "Park") ([Herschel Island](/wiki/Herschel_Island "Herschel
Island") Qikiqtaruk Territorial Park,[36] Tombstone Territorial Park,[37]
Fishing Branch Ni'iinlii'njik Park,[38] Coal River Springs Territorial
Park)[39] and [national parks](/wiki/National_Parks_of_Canada "National Parks
of Canada") ([Kluane National Park and
Reserve](/wiki/Kluane_National_Park_and_Reserve "Kluane National Park and
Reserve"), [Vuntut National Park](/wiki/Vuntut_National_Park "Vuntut National
Park"), [Ivvavik National Park](/wiki/Ivvavik_National_Park "Ivvavik National
Park")) and [reserves](/wiki/Nature_reserve "Nature reserve"), or nearby
[Liard River Hot Springs Provincial
Park](/wiki/Liard_River_Hot_Springs_Provincial_Park "Liard River Hot Springs
Provincial Park") in British Columbia.

The latitude enables the view of [aurora borealis](/wiki/Aurora_\(astronomy\)
"Aurora \(astronomy\)") in Yukon.

## Arts and culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Arts and culture")]

See also: [Music of Yukon](/wiki/Music_of_Yukon "Music of Yukon")

Although English is the main language used in the territory, as evidenced by
the census, the Government of Yukon recognizes several aboriginal languages as
part of the cultural heritage of the territory: the
[Tlingit](/wiki/Tlingit_language "Tlingit language"), and the less common
[Tahltan](/wiki/Tahltan "Tahltan"), as well as seven Athapaskan languages,
[Upper Tanana](/wiki/Upper_Tanana "Upper Tanana"), [Gwitchin](/wiki/Gwitchin
"Gwitchin"), [Hän](/wiki/H%C3%A4n_people "Hän people"), [Northern
Tutchone](/wiki/Northern_Tutchone "Northern Tutchone"), [Southern
Tutchone](/wiki/Southern_Tutchone "Southern Tutchone"), [Kaska](/wiki/Kaska
"Kaska") and [Tagish](/wiki/Tagish "Tagish"), some of which are rare.[40] As
noted above, the "aboriginal identity population" makes up a substantial
minority, accounting for about 25 percent. Notwithstanding, the aboriginal
culture is strongly reflected in such areas as winter sports, as in the [Yukon
Quest](/wiki/Yukon_Quest "Yukon Quest") sled dog race. The modern comic-book
character [Yukon Jack](/wiki/Yukon_Jack "Yukon Jack") depicts a heroic
aboriginal persona. By far the strongest cultural and tourism aspect of Yukon,
however, is the legacy of the [Klondike Gold Rush](/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush
"Klondike Gold Rush") (1897–1899), which inspired such contemporary writers at
the time as [Robert W. Service](/wiki/Robert_W._Service "Robert W. Service"),
[Jack London](/wiki/Jack_London "Jack London") and [Jules
Verne](/wiki/Jules_Verne "Jules Verne") and which continues to inspire films
and games from Mae West's _[Klondike Annie](/wiki/Klondike_Annie "Klondike
Annie")_ to [The Yukon Trail](/wiki/The_Yukon_Trail "The Yukon Trail") (_see_
[Cultural legacy of the Klondike Gold
Rush](/wiki/Cultural_legacy_of_the_Klondike_Gold_Rush "Cultural legacy of the
Klondike Gold Rush")). Notable residents have included [Leslie
Nielsen](/wiki/Leslie_Nielsen "Leslie Nielsen"), [Erik
Nielsen](/wiki/Erik_Nielsen "Erik Nielsen") and [Pierre
Berton](/wiki/Pierre_Berton "Pierre Berton").

### Events and
festivals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Events and festivals")]

See also: [Category:Festivals in Yukon](/wiki/Category:Festivals_in_Yukon
"Category:Festivals in Yukon")

Yukon also has a wide array of cultural and sporting events and
infrastructures that attract [artists](/wiki/Artist "Artist"), participants
and tourists from all parts of the world; [Yukon International Storytelling
Festival](/wiki/Yukon_International_Storytelling_Festival "Yukon International
Storytelling Festival"), Dawson City Music Festival,[41] [Yukon
Quest](/wiki/Yukon_Quest "Yukon Quest"), [Yukon Sourdough
Rendezvous](/wiki/Yukon_Sourdough_Rendezvous "Yukon Sourdough Rendezvous"),
the [Adäka Cultural Festival](/wiki/Ad%C3%A4ka_Cultural_Festival "Adäka
Cultural Festival"), the [Yukon Beringia Interpretive
Centre](/wiki/Yukon_Beringia_Interpretive_Centre "Yukon Beringia Interpretive
Centre"),[42] Northern Lights Centre,[43] Klondike Gold Rush memorials and
activities, [Takhini Hot Springs](/wiki/Takhini_Hot_Springs "Takhini Hot
Springs"), and the Whitehorse fish ladder.[44]

## Government[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Government")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Chief_Isaac_of_Han.jpg/220px-
Chief_Isaac_of_Han.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chief_Isaac_of_Han.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chief_Isaac_of_Han.jpg "Enlarge")

Chief Isaac of the Hän, Yukon Territory, 1898

In the 19th century, Yukon was a segment of [North-Western
Territory](/wiki/North-Western_Territory "North-Western Territory") that was
administered by the [Hudson's Bay Company](/wiki/Hudson%27s_Bay_Company
"Hudson's Bay Company"), and then of the Northwest Territories administered by
the federal Canadian government. It only obtained a recognizable local
government in 1895 when it became a separate [district of the Northwest
Territories](/wiki/Districts_of_the_Northwest_Territories "Districts of the
Northwest Territories").[45] In 1898, it was made a separate territory with
its own commissioner and an appointed Territorial Council.[46]

Prior to 1979, the territory was administered by the
[commissioner](/wiki/Commissioner#Canadian_territories "Commissioner") who was
appointed by the federal [Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern
Development](/wiki/Minister_of_Indian_Affairs_and_Northern_Development_\(Canada\)
"Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development \(Canada\)"). The
commissioner had a role in appointing the territory's _Executive Council_ ,
served as chair, and had a day-to-day role in governing the territory. The
elected _Territorial Council_ had a purely advisory role. In 1979, a
significant degree of power was [devolved](/wiki/Devolution "Devolution") from
the commissioner and the federal government to the territorial legislature
which, in that year, adopted a party system of [responsible
government](/wiki/Responsible_government "Responsible government"). This
change was accomplished through a letter from [Jake Epp](/wiki/Jake_Epp "Jake
Epp"), the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, rather than
through formal legislation.

In preparation for [responsible government](/wiki/Responsible_government
"Responsible government"), political parties were organized and ran candidates
to the [Yukon Legislative Assembly](/wiki/Yukon_Legislative_Assembly "Yukon
Legislative Assembly") for the first time in 1978. The [Progressive
Conservatives](/wiki/Yukon_Party "Yukon Party") won these elections and formed
the first party government of Yukon in January 1979. The [Yukon New Democratic
Party](/wiki/Yukon_New_Democratic_Party "Yukon New Democratic Party") (NDP)
formed the government from 1985 to 1992 under [Tony
Penikett](/wiki/Tony_Penikett "Tony Penikett") and again from 1996 under
[Piers McDonald](/wiki/Piers_McDonald "Piers McDonald") until being defeated
in 2000. The conservatives returned to power in 1992 under [John
Ostashek](/wiki/John_Ostashek "John Ostashek") after having renamed themselves
the [Yukon Party](/wiki/Yukon_Party "Yukon Party"). The
[Liberal](/wiki/Yukon_Liberal_Party "Yukon Liberal Party") government of [Pat
Duncan](/wiki/Pat_Duncan "Pat Duncan") was defeated in elections in November
2002, with [Dennis Fentie](/wiki/Dennis_Fentie "Dennis Fentie") of the Yukon
Party forming the government as [Premier](/wiki/Premier_\(Canada\) "Premier
\(Canada\)").

The _Yukon Act_ , passed on April 1, 2003, formalized the powers of the Yukon
government and devolved additional powers to the territorial government (e.g.,
control over land and natural resources). As of 2003, other than criminal
prosecutions, the Yukon government has much of the same powers as provincial
governments, and the other two territories are looking to obtaining the same
powers.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Today the role of commissioner is analogous to that of a provincial
[lieutenant governor](/wiki/Lieutenant_governor "Lieutenant governor");
however, unlike lieutenant-governors, commissioners are not formal
representatives of the [Queen](/wiki/Monarchy_of_Canada "Monarchy of Canada")
but are employees of the federal government.

Although there has been discussion in the past about Yukon becoming Canada's
11th province, it is generally felt[_[by
whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] that its population base is too
sparse for this to occur at present.

At the federal level, the territory is represented in the [Parliament of
Canada](/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada "Parliament of Canada") by a single [Member
of Parliament](/wiki/Member_of_Parliament "Member of Parliament") and one
[senator](/wiki/Senate_of_Canada "Senate of Canada"). Members of Parliament
from Canadian territories are full and equal voting representatives and
residents of the territory enjoy the same rights as other Canadian citizens.
One Yukon Member of Parliament, [Erik Nielsen](/wiki/Erik_Nielsen "Erik
Nielsen"), was the [Deputy Prime
Minister](/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Canada "Deputy Prime Minister of
Canada") under the government of [Brian Mulroney](/wiki/Brian_Mulroney "Brian
Mulroney"), while another, [Audrey McLaughlin](/wiki/Audrey_McLaughlin "Audrey
McLaughlin"), was the leader of the federal [New Democratic
Party](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_\(Canada\) "New Democratic Party
\(Canada\)") from 1989 to 1995.

### Federal
representation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Federal representation")]

Main article: [Yukon (electoral district)](/wiki/Yukon_\(electoral_district\)
"Yukon \(electoral district\)")

The entire territory is one [riding](/wiki/Electoral_district_\(Canada\)
"Electoral district \(Canada\)") (electoral district) in the [Canadian House
of Commons](/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_Canada "House of Commons of Canada"),
also called [Yukon](/wiki/Yukon_\(electoral_district\) "Yukon \(electoral
district\)"). The current holder of the seat is
[Liberal](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Canada "Liberal Party of Canada") Member of
Parliament [Larry Bagnell](/wiki/Larry_Bagnell "Larry Bagnell") following his
victory in the [2015 federal election](/wiki/Canadian_federal_election,_2015
"Canadian federal election, 2015").

Yukon is allocated one seat in the [Senate of Canada](/wiki/Senate_of_Canada
"Senate of Canada") and has been represented by three Senators since the
position was created in 1975. The Senate position is held by
[Conservative](/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Canada "Conservative Party of
Canada") senator [Daniel Lang](/wiki/Daniel_Lang_\(Yukon_politician\) "Daniel
Lang \(Yukon politician\)"), who was appointed by then-Prime Minister [Stephen
Harper](/wiki/Stephen_Harper "Stephen Harper") on December 22, 2008.[47][48]
It was previously filled by [Ione Christensen](/wiki/Ione_Christensen "Ione
Christensen"), of the [Liberal Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Canada "Liberal
Party of Canada"). Appointed to the Senate in 1999 by Prime Minister [Jean
Chrétien](/wiki/Jean_Chr%C3%A9tien "Jean Chrétien"), Christensen resigned in
December 2006 to help her ailing husband. From 1975 to 1999, [Paul
Lucier](/wiki/Paul_Lucier "Paul Lucier") (Liberal) served as Senator for
Yukon. Lucier was appointed by Prime Minister [Pierre
Trudeau](/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau "Pierre Trudeau").

### First Nations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: First Nations")]

Much of the population of the territory is [First Nations](/wiki/First_Nations "First Nations"). An [umbrella land claim agreement](/wiki/Yukon_Land_Claims "Yukon Land Claims") representing 7,000 members of 14 different First Nations was signed with the federal government in 1993. Eleven of the 14 Yukon First Nations have negotiated and signed comprehensive land claim and self-government agreements. The 14 First Nations speak eight different languages. The territory once had an [Inuit](/wiki/Inuit "Inuit") settlement, located on [Herschel Island](/wiki/Herschel_Island "Herschel Island") off the [Arctic](/wiki/Arctic_Ocean "Arctic Ocean") coast. This settlement was dismantled in 1987 and its inhabitants relocated to the neighbouring Northwest Territories. As a result of the Inuvialuit Final Agreement, the island is now a territorial park and is known officially as Qikiqtaruk Territorial Park, Qikiqtaruk being the name of the island in [Inuvialuktun](/wiki/Inuvialuktun "Inuvialuktun"). |  | Government | Seat | Chief

## Infrastructure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Yukon&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Infrastructure")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/High_winds_and_snow.jpg/220px-
High_winds_and_snow.jpg)](/wiki/File:High_winds_and_snow.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:High_winds_and_snow.jpg "Enlarge")

Road sign on [Dempster Highway](/wiki/Dempster_Highway "Dempster Highway"),
Eagle Plains

Before modern forms of transportation, the rivers and mountain passes were the
main transportation routes for the coastal [Tlingit](/wiki/Tlingit_people
"Tlingit people") people trading with the Athabascans of which the [Chilkoot
Pass](/wiki/Chilkoot_Pass "Chilkoot Pass") and [Dalton
Trail](/wiki/Dalton_Trail "Dalton Trail"), as well as the first Europeans.

From the Gold Rush until the 1950s, riverboats plied the Yukon River, mostly
between Whitehorse and Dawson City, with some making their way further to
Alaska and over to the [Bering Sea](/wiki/Bering_Sea "Bering Sea"), and other
tributaries of the Yukon River such as the [Stewart
River](/wiki/Stewart_River_\(Yukon\) "Stewart River \(Yukon\)"). Most of the
riverboats were owned by the British-Yukon Navigation Company, an arm of the
[White Pass and Yukon Route](/wiki/White_Pass_and_Yukon_Route "White Pass and
Yukon Route"), which also operated a [narrow gauge
railway](/wiki/Narrow_gauge_railway "Narrow gauge railway") between [Skagway,
Alaska](/wiki/Skagway,_Alaska "Skagway, Alaska"), and Whitehorse. The railway
ceased operation in the 1980s with the first closure of the
[Faro](/wiki/Faro,_Yukon "Faro, Yukon") mine. It is now run during the summer
months for the tourism season, with operations as far as
[Carcross](/wiki/Carcross,_Yukon "Carcross, Yukon").

Today, major land routes include the [Alaska Highway](/wiki/Alaska_Highway
"Alaska Highway"), the [Klondike Highway](/wiki/Klondike_Highway "Klondike
Highway") (between Skagway and Dawson City), the [Haines
Highway](/wiki/Haines_Highway "Haines Highway") (between [Haines,
Alaska](/wiki/Haines,_Alaska "Haines, Alaska"), and [Haines
Junction](/wiki/Haines_Junction,_Yukon "Haines Junction, Yukon")), and the
[Dempster Highway](/wiki/Dempster_Highway "Dempster Highway") (linking
[Inuvik](/wiki/Inuvik "Inuvik"), Northwest Territories to the Klondike
Highway), all paved except for the Dempster. Other highways with less traffic
include the "[Robert Campbell Highway](/wiki/Robert_Campbell_Highway "Robert
Campbell Highway")" linking [Carmacks](/wiki/Carmacks,_Yukon "Carmacks,
Yukon") (on the Klondike Highway) to [Watson Lake](/wiki/Watson_Lake,_Yukon
"Watson Lake, Yukon") (Alaska Highway) via Faro and [Ross
River](/wiki/Ross_River,_Yukon "Ross River, Yukon"), and the "[Silver
Trail](/wiki/Silver_Trail "Silver Trail")" linking the old silver mining
communities of [Mayo](/wiki/Mayo,_Yukon "Mayo, Yukon"),
[Elsa](/wiki/Elsa,_Yukon "Elsa, Yukon") and [Keno City](/wiki/Keno_City,_Yukon
"Keno City, Yukon") to the Klondike Highway at the Stewart River bridge. Air
travel is the only way to reach the far north community of Old Crow.

[Whitehorse International
Airport](/wiki/Erik_Nielsen_Whitehorse_International_Airport "Erik Nielsen
Whitehorse International Airport") serves as the air transport infrastructure
hub, with scheduled direct flights to [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver
"Vancouver"), [Kelowna](/wiki/Kelowna "Kelowna"), [Calgary](/wiki/Calgary
"Calgary"), [Edmonton](/wiki/Edmonton "Edmonton"),
[Yellowknife](/wiki/Yellowknife "Yellowknife"), [Inuvik](/wiki/Inuvik
"Inuvik"), [Ottawa](/wiki/Ottawa "Ottawa"), [Dawson City](/wiki/Dawson_City
"Dawson City"), [Old Crow](/wiki/Old_Crow,_Yukon "Old Crow, Yukon") and
[Frankfurt](/wiki/Frankfurt "Frankfurt")[63]. [Whitehorse International
Airport](/wiki/Erik_Nielsen_Whitehorse_International_Airport "Erik Nielsen
Whitehorse International Airport") is also the headquarters and primary hub
for [Air North](/wiki/Air_North "Air North"), Yukon's Airline. Every Yukon
community is served by an [airport or community
aerodrome](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Yukon "List of airports in
Yukon").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The communities of Dawson City and Old Crow
have regular scheduled service through [Air North](/wiki/Air_North "Air
North"). Air charter businesses exist primarily to serve the tourism and
mining exploration industries.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
